chapter.title: Applications in Ubuntu
chapter.para: Ubuntu includes a selection of useful applications which are installed by default. You can start an application by pressing Applications and then selecting an application from one of the categories displayed.

sect1.title: Installing applications
sect1.para: Installing applications in Ubuntu is different to Windows. You're probably used to the Add/Remove Applications function in Control Panel. Ubuntu has a similar function that can install as well as remove applications.

A huge selection of free applications are available stored in repositories. If you would like to install additional applications, press ApplicationsAdd/Remove.... Then, browse the selection of packages available and check the ones which you would like to install. When you have finished selecting packages, press Apply and wait for the installation process to finish.
If you know the name of a specific application, you can use Synaptic (&synaptic;).
The advantage to using these methods are that you will be automatically notified of updates.

tip.title: Additional, unsupported software
tip.para: You can select Third Party Applications from the Show list box in the Add/Remove... application to see available third party applications.

sect1.title: Ubuntu equivalents to Windows programs
sect1.para: You can do anything with Ubuntu you could do in Windows. The applications are different however. You can download many of these applications and try them in Windows. What follows is a guide to Ubuntu equivalents.
